reasoning:
The critique targets a core load-bearing move in the essay: that measuring against a “best feasible” ceiling plus moral fragility implies most surviving futures lose most value (i.e., the narrow-target/no-easy-eutopia conclusion). If broad satisficing plateaus exist in the relevant sense, that would substantially undermine the paper’s main conclusion, so centrality is high.

However, the critique is mostly programmatic rather than demonstrative. It asserts that “robustly wonderful plateaus” likely exist and that the >50% threshold is benchmark-brittle, but it doesn’t engage the essay’s key supports: (i) the multiplicative/product-of-factors model meant to explain why single flaws can wipe out large fractions of attainable value; (ii) the argument that many plausible moral views are intrinsically “fussy” (linear/unbounded scaling, fat-tailed value-efficiency, bounded-but-separate aggregation sensitivity to bads); and (iii) the paper’s explicit attempt to define ‘mostly-great’ in a theory-relative, VNM-style way rather than via raw cosmic scale alone. Without showing that a wide class of plausible moral views yields thick high-value regions (or that Forethought’s formalization of ‘mostly-great’ is misguided), the refutation is partial.

Relevance is moderate: it engages Forethought’s Tier 2 commitment that eutopia/mostly-great futures are a narrow target, which is central to their flourishing-vs-survival prioritization. But it is also a fairly generic, foreseeable objection (“you’re using an extreme ceiling / perfectionism”) and doesn’t offer new evidence, a sharper model, or a specific internal tension to resolve, so it’s not maximally helpful on their current Tier 3 agenda.

Overall reflects a central but underdeveloped challenge that weakens the position somewhat rather than seriously refuting it.
title: "The paper's metric conflates 'hard to guarantee' with 'hard to achieve'"
